dn34:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
dn34:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.

dn34:1.1.3.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn34:1.1.3.comm: This discourse is similar to DN 33; seventy items are shared between the two. Here Sāriputta teaches without prompting. The scheme is more rigorous; items listed according to a specific pattern, then the same pattern is amplified one by one. The constraints of this scheme mean that, while almost all the items listed here are found elsewhere, they are mostly not known by the name used here. This sutta seems a little later than DN 33, but such conclusions should be drawn cautiously; in at least one detail, the absence of the asura realm from the “lost opportunities”, the passage here is earlier.

dn34:1.1.5.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

dn34:1.1.7.comm: The use of a verse to introduce the teachings is unusual.

dn34:1.1.8.eng: up to ten for attaining extinguishment,

dn34:1.1.9.eng: for making an end of suffering,

dn34:1.1.10.comm: This echoes Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.26.2, sarvagranthīnāṁ vipramokṣaḥ.

dn34:1.2.1.pli: Eko, āvuso, dhammo bahukāro, eko dhammo bhāvetabbo, eko dhammo pariññeyyo, eko dhammo pahātabbo, eko dhammo hānabhāgiyo, eko dhammo visesabhāgiyo, eko dhammo duppaṭivijjho, eko dhammo uppādetabbo, eko dhammo abhiññeyyo, eko dhammo sacchikātabbo.
dn34:1.2.1.eng: Reverends, one thing is helpful, one thing should be developed, one thing should be completely understood, one thing should be given up, one thing makes things worse, one thing leads to distinction, one thing is hard to comprehend, one thing should be produced, one thing should be directly known, one thing should be realized.
dn34:1.2.1.comm: Each number from one to ten follows this same scheme.

dn34:1.2.6.eng: Mindfulness of the body that is full of pleasure.

dn34:1.2.8.eng: What one thing should be completely understood?

dn34:1.2.9.eng: Contact, which is accompanied by defilements and fuels grasping.
dn34:1.2.9.comm: Compare SN 22.48:2.2, but this is the five aggregates rather than contact.

dn34:1.2.11.eng: What one thing should be given up?

dn34:1.2.20.eng: What one thing is hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.2.21.eng: The heart’s immersion of immediate result.
dn34:1.2.21.comm: This term is only found in the Ratanasutta (Snp 2.1:5.2). It means a kind of meditation that results in the realization of the Dhamma in this very life.

dn34:1.2.26.eng: What one thing should be directly known?

dn34:1.2.27.eng: All sentient beings are sustained by food.

dn34:1.2.30.eng: The unshakable release of the heart.

dn34:1.2.32.pli: Iti ime dasa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.2.32.eng: So these ten things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.3.1.pli: Dve dhammā bahukārā, dve dhammā bhāvetabbā, dve dhammā pariññeyyā, dve dhammā pahātabbā, dve dhammā hānabhāgiyā, dve dhammā visesabhāgiyā, dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhā, dve dhammā uppādetabbā, dve dhammā abhiññeyyā, dve dhammā sacchikātabbā.
dn34:1.3.1.eng: Two things are helpful, two things should be developed, two things should be completely understood, two things should be given up, two things make things worse, two things lead to distinction, two things are hard to comprehend, two things should be produced, two things should be directly known, two things should be realized.

dn34:1.3.8.eng: What two things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.3.11.eng: What two things should be given up?

dn34:1.3.12.eng: Ignorance and craving for continued existence.

dn34:1.3.15.eng: Being hard to admonish and having bad friends.

dn34:1.3.18.eng: Being easy to admonish and having good friends.

dn34:1.3.20.eng: What two things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.3.21.pli: Yo ca hetu yo ca paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya, yo ca hetu yo ca paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā.
dn34:1.3.21.eng: The causes and reasons for the corruption of sentient beings, and the causes and reasons for the purification of sentient beings.

dn34:1.3.25.eng: knowledge of ending, and knowledge of non-arising.

dn34:1.3.27.eng: What two things should be directly known?

dn34:1.3.29.pli: saṅkhatā ca dhātu asaṅkhatā ca dhātu.
dn34:1.3.29.eng: the conditioned element and the unconditioned element.
dn34:1.3.29.comm: The “unconditioned element” is Nibbāna, everything else is conditioned.

dn34:1.3.34.pli: Iti ime vīsati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.3.34.eng: So these twenty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.4.1.pli: Tayo dhammā bahukārā, tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe… tayo dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:1.4.3.eng: Associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, and practicing in line with the teaching.
dn34:1.4.3.comm: With the addition of “rational application of mind” at AN 4.249.

dn34:1.4.7.pli: savitakko savicāro samādhi, avitakko vicāramatto samādhi, avitakko avicāro samādhi.
dn34:1.4.7.eng: Immersion with placing the mind and keeping it connected. Immersion without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected. Immersion without placing the mind or keeping it connected.

dn34:1.4.9.eng: What three things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.4.11.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

dn34:1.4.13.eng: What three things should be given up?

dn34:1.4.15.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

dn34:1.4.19.pli: lobho akusalamūlaṃ, doso akusalamūlaṃ, moho akusalamūlaṃ.

dn34:1.4.23.pli: alobho kusalamūlaṃ, adoso kusalamūlaṃ, amoho kusalamūlaṃ.

dn34:1.4.25.eng: What three things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.4.27.pli: kāmānametaṃ nissaraṇaṃ yadidaṃ nekkhammaṃ, rūpānametaṃ nissaraṇaṃ yadidaṃ arūpaṃ, yaṃ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ, nirodho tassa nissaraṇaṃ.
dn34:1.4.27.eng: Renunciation is the escape from sensual pleasures. The formless is the escape from form. Cessation is the escape from whatever is created, conditioned, and dependently originated.

dn34:1.4.31.pli: atītaṃse ñāṇaṃ, anāgataṃse ñāṇaṃ, paccuppannaṃse ñāṇaṃ.
dn34:1.4.31.eng: knowledge regarding the past portion, the future portion, and the present portion.
dn34:1.4.31.comm: These three “portions” of knowledge are not found elsewhere, but compare eg. SN 12.34.

dn34:1.4.33.eng: What three things should be directly known?

dn34:1.4.39.pli: pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ vijjā, sattānaṃ cutūpapāte ñāṇaṃ vijjā, āsavānaṃ khaye ñāṇaṃ vijjā.
dn34:1.4.39.eng: recollection of past lives, knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings, and knowledge of the ending of defilements.

dn34:1.4.41.pli: Iti ime tiṃsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.4.41.eng: So these thirty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.5.1.pli: Cattāro dhammā bahukārā, cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe… cattāro dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:1.5.4.pli: patirūpadesavāso, sappurisūpanissayo, attasammāpaṇidhi, pubbe ca katapuññatā.
dn34:1.5.4.eng: living in a suitable region, relying on true persons, being rightly resolved in oneself, and past merit.

dn34:1.5.7.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

dn34:1.5.8.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn34:1.5.8.eng: A mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn34:1.5.9.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

dn34:1.5.11.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn34:1.5.11.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn34:1.5.13.eng: What four things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.5.15.pli: kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṃ catutthaṃ.
dn34:1.5.15.eng: edible food, whether solid or subtle; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.

dn34:1.5.17.eng: What four things should be given up?

dn34:1.5.19.eng: sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

dn34:1.5.23.eng: the yokes of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

dn34:1.5.27.eng: unyoking from the yokes of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

dn34:1.5.29.eng: What four things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.5.31.pli: hānabhāgiyo samādhi, ṭhitibhāgiyo samādhi, visesabhāgiyo samādhi, nibbedhabhāgiyo samādhi.
dn34:1.5.31.eng: immersion liable to decline, stable immersion, immersion that leads to distinction, and immersion that leads to penetration.

dn34:1.5.35.pli: dhamme ñāṇaṃ, anvaye ñāṇaṃ, pariye ñāṇaṃ, sammutiyā ñāṇaṃ.
dn34:1.5.35.eng: knowledge of the teaching, inferential knowledge, knowledge of encompassing, and conventional knowledge.

dn34:1.5.37.eng: What four things should be directly known?

dn34:1.5.39.pli: dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
dn34:1.5.39.eng: suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

dn34:1.5.42.eng: Four fruits of the ascetic life:

dn34:1.5.45.pli: Iti ime cattārīsadhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.5.45.eng: So these forty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.6.1.pli: Pañca dhammā bahukārā …pe… pañca dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:1.6.4.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
dn34:1.6.4.eng: A mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

dn34:1.6.5.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
dn34:1.6.5.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

dn34:1.6.6.pli: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya.
dn34:1.6.6.eng: They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

dn34:1.6.7.pli: Asaṭho hoti amāyāvī yathābhūtamattānaṃ āvīkattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
dn34:1.6.7.eng: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

dn34:1.6.8.pli: Āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
dn34:1.6.8.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

dn34:1.6.9.pli: Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
dn34:1.6.9.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

dn34:1.6.13.eng: pervasion with rapture, pervasion with pleasure, pervasion with mind, pervasion with light, and the basis for reviewing.
dn34:1.6.13.comm: A different group of five factors of immersion is at AN 5.28; the final factor is the same in both. The first four factors, however, appear only as part of this same group in later texts (Ne 21:5.1, Ps 1.1:246.2, Vb 16:342.2).

dn34:1.6.15.eng: What five things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.6.17.eng: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

dn34:1.6.19.eng: What five things should be given up?

dn34:1.6.21.eng: sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

dn34:1.6.25.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
dn34:1.6.25.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

dn34:1.6.26.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
dn34:1.6.26.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

dn34:1.6.27.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.

dn34:1.6.28.eng: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness.

dn34:1.6.29.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…
dn34:1.6.29.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

dn34:1.6.32.pli: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
dn34:1.6.32.eng: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

dn34:1.6.33.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
dn34:1.6.33.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

dn34:1.6.34.eng: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness.

dn34:1.6.38.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

dn34:1.6.40.eng: What five things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.6.42.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāme manasikaroto kāmesu cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.42.eng: A mendicant focuses on sensual pleasures, but on that their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

dn34:1.6.43.pli: Nekkhammaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto nekkhamme cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.43.eng: But when they focus on renunciation, on that their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

dn34:1.6.44.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ kāmehi.
dn34:1.6.44.eng: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from sensual pleasures.

dn34:1.6.45.pli: Ye ca kāmapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn34:1.6.45.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of sensual pleasures, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn34:1.6.46.eng: This is how the escape from sensual pleasures is explained.

dn34:1.6.47.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno byāpādaṃ manasikaroto byāpāde cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.47.eng: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on ill will, but their mind does not leap forth …

dn34:1.6.48.pli: Abyāpādaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto abyāpāde cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.48.eng: But when they focus on good will, their mind leaps forth …

dn34:1.6.49.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ byāpādena.
dn34:1.6.49.eng: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from ill will.

dn34:1.6.50.pli: Ye ca byāpādapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn34:1.6.50.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of ill will, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn34:1.6.51.eng: This is how the escape from ill will is explained.

dn34:1.6.52.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno vihesaṃ manasikaroto vihesāya cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.52.eng: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on harming, but their mind does not leap forth …

dn34:1.6.53.pli: Avihesaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto avihesāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.53.eng: But when they focus on compassion, their mind leaps forth …

dn34:1.6.54.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ vihesāya.
dn34:1.6.54.eng: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from harming.

dn34:1.6.55.pli: Ye ca vihesāpaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn34:1.6.55.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of harming, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn34:1.6.56.eng: This is how the escape from harming is explained.

dn34:1.6.57.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno rūpe manasikaroto rūpesu cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.57.eng: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on form, but their mind does not leap forth …

dn34:1.6.58.pli: Arūpaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto arūpe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.58.eng: But when they focus on the formless, their mind leaps forth …

dn34:1.6.59.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ rūpehi.
dn34:1.6.59.eng: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from forms.

dn34:1.6.60.pli: Ye ca rūpapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn34:1.6.60.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of form, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn34:1.6.61.eng: This is how the escape from forms is explained.

dn34:1.6.62.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno sakkāyaṃ manasikaroto sakkāye cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.62.eng: Take a case where a mendicant focuses on substantial reality, but their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

dn34:1.6.63.pli: Sakkāyanirodhaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn34:1.6.63.eng: But when they focus on the cessation of substantial reality, their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

dn34:1.6.64.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ sakkāyena.
dn34:1.6.64.eng: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from substantial reality.

dn34:1.6.65.pli: Ye ca sakkāyapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn34:1.6.65.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of substantial reality, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn34:1.6.66.eng: This is how the escape from substantial reality is explained.

dn34:1.6.70.pli: ‘ayaṃ samādhi paccuppannasukho ceva āyatiñca sukhavipāko’ti paccattaṃyeva ñāṇaṃ uppajjati.
dn34:1.6.70.eng: The following knowledges arise for you personally: ‘This immersion is blissful now, and results in bliss in the future.’

dn34:1.6.71.pli: ‘Ayaṃ samādhi ariyo nirāmiso’ti paccattaññeva ñāṇaṃ uppajjati.
dn34:1.6.71.eng: ‘This immersion is noble and not of the flesh.’

dn34:1.6.72.eng: ‘This immersion is not cultivated by reprobates.’

dn34:1.6.73.pli: ‘Ayaṃ samādhi santo paṇīto paṭippassaddhaladdho ekodibhāvādhigato, na sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato’ti paccattaṃyeva ñāṇaṃ uppajjati.
dn34:1.6.73.eng: ‘This immersion is peaceful and sublime and tranquil and unified, not held in place by forceful suppression.’

dn34:1.6.74.pli: ‘So kho panāhaṃ imaṃ samādhiṃ satova samāpajjāmi sato vuṭṭhahāmī’ti paccattaṃyeva ñāṇaṃ uppajjati.
dn34:1.6.74.eng: ‘I mindfully enter into and emerge from this immersion.’

dn34:1.6.76.eng: What five things should be directly known?

dn34:1.6.78.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī.
dn34:1.6.78.eng: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.

dn34:1.6.79.pli: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn34:1.6.79.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches it.

dn34:1.6.80.pli: Tassa atthappaṭisaṃvedino dhammapaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn34:1.6.80.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn34:1.6.81.eng: This is the first opportunity for freedom.

dn34:1.6.82.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti
dn34:1.6.82.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant. But the mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.

dn34:1.6.83.pli: yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn34:1.6.83.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they teach it in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.

dn34:1.6.84.pli: Tassa atthappaṭisaṃvedino dhammapaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn34:1.6.84.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn34:1.6.85.eng: This is the second opportunity for freedom.

dn34:1.6.86.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti. Api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti.
dn34:1.6.86.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma. But the mendicant rehearses the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it.

dn34:1.6.87.pli: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn34:1.6.87.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they rehearse it in detail as they learned and memorized it.

dn34:1.6.88.pli: Tassa atthappaṭisaṃvedino dhammapaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn34:1.6.88.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn34:1.6.89.eng: This is the third opportunity for freedom.

dn34:1.6.90.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti.
dn34:1.6.90.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma … nor does the mendicant rehearse the teaching.

dn34:1.6.91.pli: Api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati.
dn34:1.6.91.eng: But the mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

dn34:1.6.92.pli: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn34:1.6.92.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they think about and consider it in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

dn34:1.6.93.pli: Tassa atthappaṭisaṃvedino dhammapaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn34:1.6.93.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn34:1.6.94.eng: This is the fourth opportunity for freedom.

dn34:1.6.95.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati;
dn34:1.6.95.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma … nor does the mendicant rehearse the teaching … or think about it.

dn34:1.6.96.pli: api ca khvassa aññataraṃ samādhinimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya.
dn34:1.6.96.eng: But a meditation subject as a basis of immersion is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

dn34:1.6.97.pli: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno aññataraṃ samādhinimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthappaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammappaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn34:1.6.97.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how a meditation subject as a basis of immersion is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

dn34:1.6.98.pli: Tassa atthappaṭisaṃvedino dhammappaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn34:1.6.98.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn34:1.6.99.eng: This is the fifth opportunity for freedom.

dn34:1.6.103.eng: ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

dn34:1.6.105.pli: Iti ime paññāsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.6.105.eng: So these fifty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.7.1.pli: Cha dhammā bahukārā …pe… cha dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:1.7.4.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca,
dn34:1.7.4.eng: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.

dn34:1.7.5.pli: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn34:1.7.5.eng: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

dn34:1.7.6.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ …pe… ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn34:1.7.6.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness.

dn34:1.7.7.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṃ manokammaṃ …pe… ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn34:1.7.7.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness.

dn34:1.7.8.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi, tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo …pe… ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn34:1.7.8.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.

dn34:1.7.9.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu, yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo …pe… ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn34:1.7.9.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

dn34:1.7.10.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca,
dn34:1.7.10.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

dn34:1.7.11.pli: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo, saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn34:1.7.11.eng: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

dn34:1.7.15.pli: buddhānussati, dhammānussati, saṅghānussati, sīlānussati, cāgānussati, devatānussati.
dn34:1.7.15.eng: the recollection of the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, ethics, generosity, and the deities.

dn34:1.7.17.eng: What six things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.7.19.pli: cakkhāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, ghānāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ, kāyāyatanaṃ, manāyatanaṃ.
dn34:1.7.19.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

dn34:1.7.21.eng: What six things should be given up?

dn34:1.7.23.pli: rūpataṇhā, saddataṇhā, gandhataṇhā, rasataṇhā, phoṭṭhabbataṇhā, dhammataṇhā.
dn34:1.7.23.eng: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

dn34:1.7.27.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso. Dhamme …pe… saṅghe … sikkhāya … appamāde … paṭisanthāre agāravo viharati appatisso.
dn34:1.7.27.eng: A mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.

dn34:1.7.31.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari sagāravo viharati sappatisso. Dhamme …pe… saṅghe … sikkhāya … appamāde … paṭisanthāre sagāravo viharati sappatisso.
dn34:1.7.31.eng: A mendicant has respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.

dn34:1.7.33.eng: What six things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.7.36.pli: ‘mettā hi kho me, cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā,
dn34:1.7.36.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by love. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn34:1.7.37.pli: atha ca pana me byāpādo cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn34:1.7.37.eng: Yet somehow ill will still occupies my mind.’

dn34:1.7.38.pli: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn34:1.7.38.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

dn34:1.7.39.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ āvuso anavakāso yaṃ mettāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya.
dn34:1.7.39.eng: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the heart’s release by love has been developed and properly implemented,

dn34:1.7.40.pli: Atha ca panassa byāpādo cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn34:1.7.40.eng: yet somehow ill will still occupies the mind.

dn34:1.7.41.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, byāpādassa, yadidaṃ mettācetovimuttī’ti.
dn34:1.7.41.eng: For it is the heart’s release by love that is the escape from ill will.’

dn34:1.7.43.pli: ‘karuṇā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
dn34:1.7.43.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by compassion. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn34:1.7.44.pli: Atha ca pana me vihesā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn34:1.7.44.eng: Yet somehow the thought of harming still occupies my mind.’

dn34:1.7.45.pli: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo, ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi …pe…
dn34:1.7.45.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn34:1.7.46.pli: nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, vihesāya, yadidaṃ karuṇācetovimuttī’ti.
dn34:1.7.46.eng: For it is the heart’s release by compassion that is the escape from thoughts of harming.’

dn34:1.7.48.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by rejoicing. …

dn34:1.7.49.pli: atha ca pana me arati cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn34:1.7.49.eng: Yet somehow discontent still occupies my mind.’

dn34:1.7.50.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn34:1.7.51.pli: nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, aratiyā, yadidaṃ muditācetovimuttī’ti.
dn34:1.7.51.eng: For it is the heart’s release by rejoicing that is the escape from discontent.’

dn34:1.7.53.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by equanimity. …

dn34:1.7.54.pli: atha ca pana me rāgo cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn34:1.7.54.eng: Yet somehow desire still occupies my mind.’

dn34:1.7.55.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn34:1.7.56.pli: nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, rāgassa yadidaṃ upekkhācetovimuttī’ti.
dn34:1.7.56.eng: For it is the heart’s release by equanimity that is the escape from desire.’

dn34:1.7.58.eng: ‘I’ve developed the signless release of the heart. …

dn34:1.7.59.pli: atha ca pana me nimittānusāri viññāṇaṃ hotī’ti.
dn34:1.7.59.eng: Yet somehow my consciousness still follows after signs.’

dn34:1.7.60.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn34:1.7.61.pli: nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṃ yadidaṃ animittā cetovimuttī’ti.
dn34:1.7.61.eng: For it is the signless release of the heart that is the escape from all signs.’

dn34:1.7.63.pli: ‘asmīti kho me vigataṃ, ayamahamasmīti na samanupassāmi,
dn34:1.7.63.eng: ‘I’m rid of the conceit “I am”. And I don’t regard anything as “I am this”.

dn34:1.7.64.pli: atha ca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṃ cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn34:1.7.64.eng: Yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupies my mind.’

dn34:1.7.65.pli: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn34:1.7.65.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

dn34:1.7.66.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṃ asmīti vigate ayamahamasmīti asamanupassato.
dn34:1.7.66.eng: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the conceit “I am” has been done away with, and nothing is regarded as “I am this”,

dn34:1.7.67.pli: Atha ca panassa vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṃ cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn34:1.7.67.eng: yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupy the mind.

dn34:1.7.68.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallassa, yadidaṃ asmimānasamugghāto’ti.
dn34:1.7.68.eng: For it is the uprooting of the conceit “I am” that is the escape from the dart of doubt and indecision.’

dn34:1.7.72.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn34:1.7.72.eng: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn34:1.7.73.eng: Hearing a sound with their ears …

dn34:1.7.74.eng: Smelling an odor with their nose …

dn34:1.7.75.eng: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …

dn34:1.7.76.eng: Feeling a touch with their body …

dn34:1.7.77.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn34:1.7.77.eng: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn34:1.7.79.eng: What six things should be directly known?

dn34:1.7.81.pli: dassanānuttariyaṃ, savanānuttariyaṃ, lābhānuttariyaṃ, sikkhānuttariyaṃ, pāricariyānuttariyaṃ, anussatānuttariyaṃ.
dn34:1.7.81.eng: the unsurpassable seeing, listening, acquisition, training, service, and recollection.

dn34:1.7.85.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāvaṃ; tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
dn34:1.7.85.eng: A mendicant wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.

dn34:1.7.86.pli: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca.
dn34:1.7.86.eng: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.

dn34:1.7.87.pli: Parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti,
dn34:1.7.87.eng: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with their own mind.

dn34:1.7.88.pli: sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāti …pe…

dn34:1.7.89.pli: avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajānāti.

dn34:1.7.90.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
dn34:1.7.90.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dn34:1.7.91.pli: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti …pe…
dn34:1.7.91.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

dn34:1.7.92.pli: Āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
dn34:1.7.92.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

dn34:1.7.94.pli: Iti ime saṭṭhi dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.7.94.eng: So these sixty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.8.1.pli: Satta dhammā bahukārā …pe… satta dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:1.8.3.eng: Seven riches of the noble ones:

dn34:1.8.4.pli: saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ, hiridhanaṃ, ottappadhanaṃ, sutadhanaṃ, cāgadhanaṃ, paññādhanaṃ.
dn34:1.8.4.eng: the riches of faith, ethics, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

dn34:1.8.8.pli: satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.
dn34:1.8.8.eng: mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.

dn34:1.8.10.eng: What seven things should be completely understood?

dn34:1.8.12.pli: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
dn34:1.8.12.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

dn34:1.8.13.eng: This is the first plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.14.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
dn34:1.8.14.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.

dn34:1.8.15.eng: This is the second plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.16.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
dn34:1.8.16.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

dn34:1.8.17.eng: This is the third plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.18.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
dn34:1.8.18.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.

dn34:1.8.19.eng: This is the fourth plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.20.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā …pe… ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
dn34:1.8.20.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

dn34:1.8.21.eng: This is the fifth plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.22.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
dn34:1.8.22.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn34:1.8.23.eng: This is the sixth plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.24.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
dn34:1.8.24.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

dn34:1.8.25.eng: This is the seventh plane of consciousness.

dn34:1.8.27.eng: What seven things should be given up?

dn34:1.8.29.pli: kāmarāgānusayo, paṭighānusayo, diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo, mānānusayo, bhavarāgānusayo, avijjānusayo.
dn34:1.8.29.eng: sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

dn34:1.8.33.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
dn34:1.8.33.eng: a mendicant is faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.

dn34:1.8.37.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, paññavā hoti.
dn34:1.8.37.eng: a mendicant is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

dn34:1.8.39.eng: What seven things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:1.8.40.eng: Seven aspects of the teachings of the true persons:

dn34:1.8.41.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu dhammaññū ca hoti atthaññū ca attaññū ca mattaññū ca kālaññū ca parisaññū ca puggalaññū ca.
dn34:1.8.41.eng: a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, knows themselves, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows individuals.

dn34:1.8.45.pli: aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
dn34:1.8.45.eng: the perception of impermanence, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.

dn34:1.8.47.eng: What seven things should be directly known?

dn34:1.8.49.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemo.
dn34:1.8.49.eng: A mendicant has a keen enthusiasm to undertake the training …

dn34:1.8.50.pli: Dhammanisantiyā tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca dhammanisantiyā avigatapemo.

dn34:1.8.51.pli: Icchāvinaye tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca icchāvinaye avigatapemo.

dn34:1.8.52.pli: Paṭisallāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca paṭisallāne avigatapemo.

dn34:1.8.53.pli: Vīriyārambhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca vīriyārambhe avigatapemo.

dn34:1.8.54.pli: Satinepakke tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca satinepakke avigatapemo.

dn34:1.8.55.pli: Diṭṭhipaṭivedhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca diṭṭhipaṭivedhe avigatapemo.
dn34:1.8.55.eng: to penetrate theoretically. And they don’t lose these desires in the future.

dn34:1.8.58.eng: Seven powers of one who has ended the defilements.

dn34:1.8.59.pli: idhāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
dn34:1.8.59.eng: Firstly, a mendicant with defilements ended has clearly seen with right wisdom all conditions as truly impermanent.

dn34:1.8.60.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma khīṇāsavo bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayaṃ paṭijānāti: ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti.
dn34:1.8.60.eng: This is a power that a mendicant who has ended the defilements relies on to claim: ‘My defilements have ended.’

dn34:1.8.61.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
dn34:1.8.61.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has clearly seen with right wisdom that sensual pleasures are truly like a pit of glowing coals. …

dn34:1.8.63.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno vivekaninnaṃ cittaṃ hoti vivekapoṇaṃ vivekapabbhāraṃ vivekaṭṭhaṃ nekkhammābhirataṃ byantībhūtaṃ sabbaso āsavaṭṭhāniyehi dhammehi.
dn34:1.8.63.eng: Furthermore, the mind of a mendicant with defilements ended slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion. They’re withdrawn, loving renunciation, and have totally eliminated defiling influences. …

dn34:1.8.65.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
dn34:1.8.65.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …

dn34:1.8.67.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni honti subhāvitāni.
dn34:1.8.67.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the five faculties. …

dn34:1.8.69.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
dn34:1.8.69.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the seven awakening factors. …

dn34:1.8.71.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvito hoti subhāvito.
dn34:1.8.71.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the noble eightfold path. …

dn34:1.8.72.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvito hoti subhāvito, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma khīṇāsavo bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayaṃ paṭijānāti:
dn34:1.8.72.eng: This is a power that a mendicant who has ended the defilements relies on to claim:

dn34:1.8.75.pli: Itime sattati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:1.8.75.eng: So these seventy things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:1.8.76.eng: The first recitation section is finished.

dn34:2.1.1.pli: Aṭṭha dhammā bahukārā …pe… aṭṭha dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:2.1.3.pli: Aṭṭha hetū aṭṭha paccayā ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattanti.
dn34:2.1.3.eng: There are eight causes and reasons that lead to acquiring the wisdom fundamental to the spiritual life, and to its increase, growth, development, and fulfillment once it has been acquired.

dn34:2.1.5.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthāraṃ upanissāya viharati aññataraṃ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ, yatthassa tibbaṃ hirottappaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti pemañca gāravo ca.
dn34:2.1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role. And they set up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect.

dn34:2.1.6.pli: Ayaṃ paṭhamo hetu paṭhamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.7.pli: Taṃ kho pana satthāraṃ upanissāya viharati aññataraṃ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ, yatthassa tibbaṃ hirottappaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti pemañca gāravo ca. Te kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamitvā paripucchati paripañhati:
dn34:2.1.7.eng: When a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role—with a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect—from time to time they go and ask them questions:

dn34:2.1.10.pli: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṃ paṭivinodenti.
dn34:2.1.10.eng: Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.

dn34:2.1.11.pli: Ayaṃ dutiyo hetu dutiyo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.12.pli: Taṃ kho pana dhammaṃ sutvā dvayena vūpakāsena sampādeti—kāyavūpakāsena ca cittavūpakāsena ca.
dn34:2.1.12.eng: After hearing that teaching they perfect withdrawal of both body and mind.

dn34:2.1.13.pli: Ayaṃ tatiyo hetu tatiyo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.14.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
dn34:2.1.14.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

dn34:2.1.15.pli: Ayaṃ catuttho hetu catuttho paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.16.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthā sabyañjanā kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
dn34:2.1.16.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

dn34:2.1.17.pli: Ayaṃ pañcamo hetu pañcamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.18.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
dn34:2.1.18.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

dn34:2.1.19.pli: Ayaṃ chaṭṭho hetu chaṭṭho paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.20.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato. Cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
dn34:2.1.20.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

dn34:2.1.21.pli: Ayaṃ sattamo hetu sattamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.22.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu, udayabbayānupassī viharati:
dn34:2.1.22.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

dn34:2.1.23.pli: ‘iti rūpaṃ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
dn34:2.1.23.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

dn34:2.1.24.pli: iti vedanā iti vedanāya samudayo iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
dn34:2.1.24.eng: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

dn34:2.1.25.pli: iti saññā iti saññāya samudayo iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
dn34:2.1.25.eng: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.

dn34:2.1.26.pli: iti saṅkhārā iti saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo;
dn34:2.1.26.eng: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.

dn34:2.1.27.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
dn34:2.1.27.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

dn34:2.1.28.pli: Ayaṃ aṭṭhamo hetu aṭṭhamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattati.

dn34:2.1.31.eng: The noble eightfold path, that is:

dn34:2.1.32.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
dn34:2.1.32.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

dn34:2.1.34.eng: What eight things should be completely understood?

dn34:2.1.36.pli: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṃsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca.
dn34:2.1.36.eng: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.

dn34:2.1.38.eng: What eight things should be given up?

dn34:2.1.40.pli: micchādiṭṭhi, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvācā, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi.
dn34:2.1.40.eng: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

dn34:2.1.44.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.

dn34:2.1.46.pli: ‘kammaṃ kho me kātabbaṃ bhavissati, kammaṃ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilamissati, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
dn34:2.1.46.eng: ‘I have some work to do. But while doing it my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

dn34:2.1.47.pli: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
dn34:2.1.47.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

dn34:2.1.48.eng: This is the first ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.49.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kataṃ hoti.
dn34:2.1.49.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.

dn34:2.1.51.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho kammaṃ akāsiṃ, kammaṃ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilanto, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
dn34:2.1.51.eng: ‘I’ve done some work. But while working my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

dn34:2.1.52.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…

dn34:2.1.53.eng: This is the second ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.54.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
dn34:2.1.54.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.

dn34:2.1.56.pli: ‘maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati, maggaṃ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilamissati, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
dn34:2.1.56.eng: ‘I have to go on a journey. But while walking my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

dn34:2.1.57.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…

dn34:2.1.58.eng: This is the third ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.59.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
dn34:2.1.59.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.

dn34:2.1.61.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho maggaṃ agamāsiṃ, maggaṃ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilanto, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
dn34:2.1.61.eng: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. But while walking my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

dn34:2.1.62.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…

dn34:2.1.63.eng: This is the fourth ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.64.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
dn34:2.1.64.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

dn34:2.1.66.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ, tassa me kāyo kilanto akammañño, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti …pe…
dn34:2.1.66.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is tired and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’…

dn34:2.1.67.eng: This is the fifth ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.68.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
dn34:2.1.68.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

dn34:2.1.70.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ, tassa me kāyo garuko akammañño, māsācitaṃ maññe, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
dn34:2.1.70.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is heavy, unfit for work, like I’ve just eaten a load of beans. I’d better have a lie down.’…

dn34:2.1.71.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…

dn34:2.1.72.eng: This is the sixth ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.73.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno uppanno hoti appamattako ābādho, tassa evaṃ hoti:
dn34:2.1.73.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick. They think:

dn34:2.1.74.pli: ‘uppanno kho me ayaṃ appamattako ābādho atthi kappo nipajjituṃ, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.
dn34:2.1.74.eng: ‘I feel a little sick. Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’

dn34:2.1.75.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…

dn34:2.1.76.eng: This is the seventh ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.77.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu gilānāvuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
dn34:2.1.77.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.

dn34:2.1.79.eng: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. My body is weak and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’

dn34:2.1.80.pli: Tassa me kāyo dubbalo akammañño, handāhaṃ nipajjāmī’ti.

dn34:2.1.81.eng: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…

dn34:2.1.82.eng: This is the eighth ground for laziness.

dn34:2.1.86.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kātabbaṃ hoti, tassa evaṃ hoti:
dn34:2.1.86.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do. They think:

dn34:2.1.87.pli: ‘kammaṃ kho me kātabbaṃ bhavissati, kammaṃ kho pana me karontena na sukaraṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasikātuṃ, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
dn34:2.1.87.eng: ‘I have some work to do. While working it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

dn34:2.1.88.pli: So vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
dn34:2.1.88.eng: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

dn34:2.1.89.eng: This is the first ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.90.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṃ kataṃ hoti.
dn34:2.1.90.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.

dn34:2.1.92.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho kammaṃ akāsiṃ, kammaṃ kho panāhaṃ karonto nāsakkhiṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasikātuṃ, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
dn34:2.1.92.eng: ‘I’ve done some work. While I was working I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…

dn34:2.1.93.eng: This is the second ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.94.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
dn34:2.1.94.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.

dn34:2.1.96.pli: ‘maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati, maggaṃ kho pana me gacchantena na sukaraṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasikātuṃ, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
dn34:2.1.96.eng: ‘I have to go on a journey. While walking it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…

dn34:2.1.97.eng: This is the third ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.98.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
dn34:2.1.98.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.

dn34:2.1.100.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho maggaṃ agamāsiṃ, maggaṃ kho panāhaṃ gacchanto nāsakkhiṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ manasikātuṃ, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
dn34:2.1.100.eng: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. While I was walking I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…

dn34:2.1.101.eng: This is the fourth ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.102.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
dn34:2.1.102.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

dn34:2.1.104.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ, tassa me kāyo lahuko kammañño, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
dn34:2.1.104.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is light and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…

dn34:2.1.105.eng: This is the fifth ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.106.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
dn34:2.1.106.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

dn34:2.1.108.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṃ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṃ pāripūriṃ.
dn34:2.1.108.eng: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is strong and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…

dn34:2.1.109.pli: Tassa me kāyo balavā kammañño, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…

dn34:2.1.110.eng: This is the sixth ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.111.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno uppanno hoti appamattako ābādho.
dn34:2.1.111.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick.

dn34:2.1.113.pli: ‘uppanno kho me ayaṃ appamattako ābādho ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati, yaṃ me ābādho pavaḍḍheyya, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi …pe…
dn34:2.1.113.eng: ‘I feel a little sick. It’s possible this illness will worsen. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’…

dn34:2.1.114.eng: This is the seventh ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.115.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu gilānā vuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
dn34:2.1.115.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.

dn34:2.1.117.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati, yaṃ me ābādho paccudāvatteyya, handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
dn34:2.1.117.eng: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. It’s possible the illness will come back. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

dn34:2.1.118.pli: So vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
dn34:2.1.118.eng: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

dn34:2.1.119.eng: This is the eighth ground for arousing energy.

dn34:2.1.121.eng: What eight things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:2.1.122.eng: Eight lost opportunities for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.123.pli: Idhāvuso, tathāgato ca loke uppanno hoti arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito.
dn34:2.1.123.eng: Firstly, a Realized One has arisen in the world. He teaches the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One.

dn34:2.1.124.eng: But that individual has been reborn in hell.

dn34:2.1.125.eng: This is the first lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.126.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, tathāgato ca loke uppanno hoti arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito.
dn34:2.1.126.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn34:2.1.127.eng: But that individual has been reborn in the animal realm.

dn34:2.1.128.eng: This is the second lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.129.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn34:2.1.130.eng: But that individual has been reborn in the ghost realm.

dn34:2.1.131.eng: This is the third lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.132.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
dn34:2.1.132.comm: At this point, DN 33:3.2.53 has an extra possibility, rebirth among the titans, making nine in all.

dn34:2.1.133.eng: But that individual has been reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods.

dn34:2.1.134.eng: This is the fourth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.135.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn34:2.1.136.pli: paccantimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti milakkhesu aviññātāresu, yattha natthi gati bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
dn34:2.1.136.eng: But that individual has been reborn in the borderlands, among uneducated foreigners, where monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen do not go.

dn34:2.1.137.eng: This is the fifth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.138.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn34:2.1.139.pli: ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti micchādiṭṭhiko viparītadassano:
dn34:2.1.139.eng: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they have wrong view and distorted perspective:

dn34:2.1.140.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
dn34:2.1.140.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

dn34:2.1.141.eng: This is the sixth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.142.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn34:2.1.143.pli: ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti duppañño jaḷo eḷamūgo, nappaṭibalo subhāsitadubbhāsitānamatthamaññātuṃ.
dn34:2.1.143.eng: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they’re witless, dull, idiotic, and unable to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.

dn34:2.1.144.eng: This is the seventh lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.145.eng: Furthermore, no Realized One has arisen in the world,
dn34:2.1.145.comm: The negative is absent from the text due to abbreviation, so it is inferred from the parallel passage at DN 33:3.2.69.

dn34:2.1.146.pli: ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti paññavā ajaḷo aneḷamūgo, paṭibalo subhāsitadubbhāsitānamatthamaññātuṃ.
dn34:2.1.146.eng: so there is no teaching of the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One. But an individual is reborn in a central country. And they’re wise, bright, clever, and able to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.

dn34:2.1.147.eng: This is the eighth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn34:2.1.150.eng: Eight thoughts of a great man.

dn34:2.1.151.eng: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.

dn34:2.1.152.eng: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.

dn34:2.1.153.eng: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.

dn34:2.1.154.eng: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.

dn34:2.1.155.eng: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.

dn34:2.1.156.eng: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.

dn34:2.1.157.pli: Paññavato ayaṃ dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo duppaññassa.
dn34:2.1.157.eng: It’s for the wise, not the witless.

dn34:2.1.158.pli: Nippapañcassāyaṃ dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassāti ime aṭṭha dhammā uppādetabbā.
dn34:2.1.158.eng: This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating, not for those who enjoy proliferating.’
dn34:2.1.158.comm: AN 8.30. | Read nippapañcārāmassāyaṁ per AN 8.30:3.11.

dn34:2.1.159.eng: What eight things should be directly known?

dn34:2.1.161.pli: ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
dn34:2.1.161.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.163.eng: This is the first dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.164.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
dn34:2.1.164.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.166.eng: This is the second dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.167.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
dn34:2.1.167.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.169.eng: This is the third dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.170.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
dn34:2.1.170.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.172.eng: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.173.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
dn34:2.1.173.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

dn34:2.1.174.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma umāpupphaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ;
dn34:2.1.174.eng: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

dn34:2.1.175.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn34:2.1.175.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.176.eng: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.177.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
dn34:2.1.177.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn34:2.1.178.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kaṇikārapupphaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ;
dn34:2.1.178.eng: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn34:2.1.179.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn34:2.1.179.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.180.eng: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.181.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
dn34:2.1.181.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.

dn34:2.1.182.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma bandhujīvakapupphaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ;
dn34:2.1.182.eng: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.

dn34:2.1.183.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn34:2.1.183.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.184.eng: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.185.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
dn34:2.1.185.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.

dn34:2.1.186.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma osadhitārakā odātā odātavaṇṇā odātanidassanā odātanibhāsā, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ odātaṃ odātavaṇṇaṃ odātanidassanaṃ odātanibhāsaṃ;
dn34:2.1.186.eng: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.

dn34:2.1.187.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn34:2.1.187.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn34:2.1.188.eng: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.

dn34:2.1.192.eng: Having physical form, they see forms.

dn34:2.1.194.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati.
dn34:2.1.194.eng: Not perceiving physical form internally, someone see forms externally.

dn34:2.1.198.pli: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.1.198.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

dn34:2.1.200.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.1.200.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn34:2.1.202.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.1.202.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

dn34:2.1.204.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.1.204.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn34:2.1.206.pli: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.1.206.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

dn34:2.1.209.pli: Iti ime asīti dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:2.1.209.eng: So these eighty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:2.2.1.pli: Nava dhammā bahukārā …pe… nava dhammā sacchikātabbā.

dn34:2.2.3.pli: Nava yonisomanasikāramūlakā dhammā, yonisomanasikaroto pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati, samāhite citte yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati, yathābhūtaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ nibbindati, nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati.
dn34:2.2.3.eng: Nine things rooted in rational application of mind. When you apply the mind rationally, joy springs up. When you’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, you feel bliss. And when you’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed. When your mind is immersed, you truly know and see. When you truly know and see, you grow disillusioned. Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away you’re freed.
dn34:2.2.3.comm: Similar sequences are found throughout the suttas, but this exact sequence appears to be unique.

dn34:2.2.6.eng: Nine factors of trying to be pure.

dn34:2.2.7.pli: sīlavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, cittavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, diṭṭhivisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, ñāṇadassanavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, paññāvisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ, vimuttivisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṃ.
