dn34:2.2.7.eng: The factors of trying to be pure in ethics, mind, view, overcoming doubt, knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path, knowledge and vision of the practice, knowledge and vision, wisdom, and freedom.
dn34:2.2.7.comm: Four are found at AN 4.194. Seven, phrased slightly differently, are found at MN 23.

dn34:2.2.9.eng: What nine things should be completely understood?

dn34:2.2.11.pli: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
dn34:2.2.11.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

dn34:2.2.12.eng: This is the first abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.13.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
dn34:2.2.13.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.

dn34:2.2.14.eng: This is the second abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.15.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
dn34:2.2.15.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

dn34:2.2.16.eng: This is the third abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.17.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
dn34:2.2.17.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.

dn34:2.2.18.eng: This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.19.pli: Santāvuso, sattā asaññino appaṭisaṃvedino, seyyathāpi devā asaññasattā.
dn34:2.2.19.eng: There are sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything, such as the gods who are non-percipient beings.

dn34:2.2.20.eng: This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.21.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
dn34:2.2.21.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

dn34:2.2.22.eng: This is the sixth abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.23.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
dn34:2.2.23.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn34:2.2.24.eng: This is the seventh abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.25.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
dn34:2.2.25.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

dn34:2.2.26.eng: This is the eighth abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.27.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagā.
dn34:2.2.27.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. They have been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn34:2.2.28.eng: This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.

dn34:2.2.30.eng: What nine things should be given up?

dn34:2.2.32.pli: taṇhaṃ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṃ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo, vinicchayaṃ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṃ paṭicca ajjhosānaṃ, ajjhosānaṃ paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṃ paṭicca macchariyaṃ, macchariyaṃ paṭicca ārakkho, ārakkhādhikaraṇaṃ daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṃtuvaṃpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
dn34:2.2.32.eng: Craving gives rise to searching. Searching gives rise to gaining material things. Gaining material things gives rise to evaluation. Evaluation gives rise to desire and lust. Desire and lust gives rise to attachment. Attachment gives rise to ownership. Ownership gives rise to stinginess. Stinginess gives rise to safeguarding. Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, disputes, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.

dn34:2.2.36.eng: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me,’ you harbor resentment.

dn34:2.2.37.eng: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me’ …

dn34:2.2.39.pli: ‘piyassa me manāpassa anatthaṃ acarī’ti āghātaṃ bandhati …pe…
dn34:2.2.39.eng: ‘They did wrong by someone I love’ …

dn34:2.2.40.eng: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love’ …

dn34:2.2.41.eng: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love’ …

dn34:2.2.42.pli: ‘appiyassa me amanāpassa atthaṃ acarī’ti āghātaṃ bandhati …pe…

dn34:2.2.44.eng: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike,’ you harbor resentment.

dn34:2.2.47.eng: Nine ways to get rid of resentment.

dn34:2.2.48.pli: ‘anatthaṃ me acari, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;
dn34:2.2.48.eng: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.

dn34:2.2.49.pli: ‘anatthaṃ me carati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;
dn34:2.2.49.eng: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me …’ …

dn34:2.2.50.pli: ‘anatthaṃ me carissati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;

dn34:2.2.51.eng: ‘They did wrong by someone I love …’ …

dn34:2.2.52.eng: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love …’ …

dn34:2.2.53.pli: anatthaṃ carissati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;
dn34:2.2.53.eng: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love …’ …

dn34:2.2.56.pli: atthaṃ carissati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti.
dn34:2.2.56.eng: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.

dn34:2.2.58.eng: What nine things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:2.2.60.pli: dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ, vedanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṃ, pariyesanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati lābhanānattaṃ (…).
dn34:2.2.60.eng: Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings. Diversity of feelings gives rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of thoughts. Diversity of thoughts gives rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches. Diversity of searches gives rise to diversity of gains.

dn34:2.2.64.pli: asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā.
dn34:2.2.64.eng: the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away.

dn34:2.2.66.eng: What nine things should be directly known?

dn34:2.2.68.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.2.68.eng: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …

dn34:2.2.69.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

dn34:2.2.70.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

dn34:2.2.71.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.

dn34:2.2.72.pli: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā …pe… ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.2.72.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

dn34:2.2.73.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.2.73.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn34:2.2.74.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.2.74.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

dn34:2.2.75.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.2.75.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn34:2.2.76.pli: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.2.76.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

dn34:2.2.80.pli: paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa kāmasaññā niruddhā hoti,
dn34:2.2.80.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, sensual perceptions have ceased.

dn34:2.2.81.pli: dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā niruddhā honti,
dn34:2.2.81.eng: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.

dn34:2.2.82.pli: tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa pīti niruddhā hoti,
dn34:2.2.82.eng: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.

dn34:2.2.83.pli: catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāssā niruddhā honti,
dn34:2.2.83.eng: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.

dn34:2.2.84.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.

dn34:2.2.85.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.

dn34:2.2.86.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.

dn34:2.2.87.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.

dn34:2.2.88.pli: saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti.
dn34:2.2.88.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.

dn34:2.2.90.pli: Iti ime navuti dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
dn34:2.2.90.eng: So these ninety things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.

dn34:2.3.1.pli: Dasa dhammā bahukārā …pe… dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā.
dn34:2.3.1.eng: Ten things are helpful, ten things should be developed, ten things should be completely understood, ten things should be given up, ten things make things worse, ten things lead to distinction, ten things are hard to comprehend, ten things should be produced, ten things should be directly known, ten things should be realized.

dn34:2.3.3.eng: Ten qualities that serve as protector.

dn34:2.3.4.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
dn34:2.3.4.eng: First, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

dn34:2.3.5.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.

dn34:2.3.6.eng: This is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.7.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

dn34:2.3.9.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.10.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
dn34:2.3.10.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.

dn34:2.3.12.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.13.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato, khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṃ.
dn34:2.3.13.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.

dn34:2.3.15.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.16.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tattha dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgato, alaṃ kātuṃ, alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.
dn34:2.3.16.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

dn34:2.3.18.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.19.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
dn34:2.3.19.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.

dn34:2.3.21.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.22.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarehi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi.
dn34:2.3.22.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

dn34:2.3.24.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.25.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati …pe… kusalesu dhammesu.

dn34:2.3.27.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.28.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti, paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
dn34:2.3.28.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

dn34:2.3.30.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.31.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato, ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
dn34:2.3.31.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

dn34:2.3.33.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn34:2.3.37.pli: pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
dn34:2.3.37.eng: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.

dn34:2.3.38.eng: They perceive the meditation on universal water …

dn34:2.3.46.pli: viññāṇakasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
dn34:2.3.46.eng: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.

dn34:2.3.48.eng: What ten things should be completely understood?

dn34:2.3.50.pli: cakkhāyatanaṃ, rūpāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, saddāyatanaṃ, ghānāyatanaṃ, gandhāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ, rasāyatanaṃ, kāyāyatanaṃ, phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ.
dn34:2.3.50.eng: eye and sights, ear and sounds, nose and smells, tongue and tastes, body and touches.

dn34:2.3.52.eng: What ten things should be given up?

dn34:2.3.54.pli: micchādiṭṭhi, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvācā, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi, micchāñāṇaṃ, micchāvimutti.
dn34:2.3.54.eng: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

dn34:2.3.57.eng: Ten ways of doing unskillful deeds:

dn34:2.3.58.pli: pāṇātipāto, adinnādānaṃ, kāmesumicchācāro, musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo, abhijjhā, byāpādo, micchādiṭṭhi.
dn34:2.3.58.eng: killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.

dn34:2.3.61.eng: Ten ways of doing skillful deeds:

dn34:2.3.62.pli: pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī, musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī, anabhijjhā, abyāpādo, sammādiṭṭhi.
dn34:2.3.62.eng: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.

dn34:2.3.64.eng: What ten things are hard to comprehend?

dn34:2.3.65.eng: Ten abodes of the noble ones.

dn34:2.3.66.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti, chaḷaṅgasamannāgato, ekārakkho, caturāpasseno, paṇunnapaccekasacco, samavayasaṭṭhesano, anāvilasaṅkappo, passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro, suvimuttacitto, suvimuttapañño.
dn34:2.3.66.eng: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.

dn34:2.3.67.eng: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?

dn34:2.3.68.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti.
dn34:2.3.68.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

dn34:2.3.69.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti.
dn34:2.3.69.eng: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.

dn34:2.3.70.eng: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?

dn34:2.3.71.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn34:2.3.71.eng: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn34:2.3.72.eng: Hearing a sound with their ears …

dn34:2.3.73.eng: Smelling an odor with their nose …

dn34:2.3.74.eng: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …

dn34:2.3.75.eng: Feeling a touch with their body …

dn34:2.3.76.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn34:2.3.76.eng: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn34:2.3.77.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hoti.
dn34:2.3.77.eng: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.

dn34:2.3.78.eng: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?

dn34:2.3.79.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satārakkhena cetasā samannāgato hoti.
dn34:2.3.79.eng: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.

dn34:2.3.80.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu ekārakkho hoti.
dn34:2.3.80.eng: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.

dn34:2.3.81.eng: And how does a mendicant have four supports?

dn34:2.3.82.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti.
dn34:2.3.82.eng: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

dn34:2.3.83.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu caturāpasseno hoti.
dn34:2.3.83.eng: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.

dn34:2.3.84.eng: And how has a mendicant cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?

dn34:2.3.85.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno yāni tāni puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ puthupaccekasaccāni, sabbāni tāni nunnāni honti paṇunnāni cattāni vantāni muttāni pahīnāni paṭinissaṭṭhāni.
dn34:2.3.85.eng: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. A mendicant has cast out, cast aside, thrown out, discarded, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.

dn34:2.3.86.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu paṇunnapaccekasacco hoti.
dn34:2.3.86.eng: That’s how a mendicant has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.

dn34:2.3.87.eng: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?

dn34:2.3.88.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmesanā pahīnā hoti, bhavesanā pahīnā hoti, brahmacariyesanā paṭippassaddhā.
dn34:2.3.88.eng: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.

dn34:2.3.89.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu samavayasaṭṭhesano hoti.
dn34:2.3.89.eng: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.

dn34:2.3.90.eng: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?

dn34:2.3.91.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, byāpādasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, vihiṃsāsaṅkappo pahīno hoti.
dn34:2.3.91.eng: It’s when they’ve given up sensual, malicious, and cruel intentions.

dn34:2.3.92.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu anāvilasaṅkappo hoti.
dn34:2.3.92.eng: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.

dn34:2.3.93.eng: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?

dn34:2.3.94.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn34:2.3.94.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn34:2.3.95.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro hoti.
dn34:2.3.95.eng: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.

dn34:2.3.96.eng: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?

dn34:2.3.97.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti.
dn34:2.3.97.eng: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.

dn34:2.3.98.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttacitto hoti.
dn34:2.3.98.eng: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.

dn34:2.3.99.eng: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?

dn34:2.3.100.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ‘rāgo me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.
dn34:2.3.100.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’

dn34:2.3.105.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttapañño hoti.
dn34:2.3.105.eng: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.

dn34:2.3.109.pli: asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
dn34:2.3.109.eng: the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.

dn34:2.3.111.eng: What ten things should be directly known?

dn34:2.3.113.eng: For one of right view, wrong view is worn away.

dn34:2.3.114.pli: Ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
dn34:2.3.114.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are worn away.

dn34:2.3.115.eng: For one of right intention, wrong intention is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.116.eng: For one of right speech, wrong speech is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.117.eng: For one of right action, wrong action is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.118.eng: For one of right livelihood, wrong livelihood is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.119.eng: For one of right effort, wrong effort is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.120.eng: For one of right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.121.eng: For one of right immersion, wrong immersion is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.122.eng: For one of right knowledge, wrong knowledge is worn away. …

dn34:2.3.123.eng: For one of right freedom, wrong freedom is worn away.

dn34:2.3.124.pli: Ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
dn34:2.3.124.eng: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are worn away.

dn34:2.3.128.pli: asekkhā sammādiṭṭhi, asekkho sammāsaṅkappo, asekkhā sammāvācā, asekkho sammākammanto, asekkho sammāājīvo, asekkho sammāvāyāmo, asekkhā sammāsati, asekkho sammāsamādhi, asekkhaṃ sammāñāṇaṃ, asekkhā sammāvimutti.
dn34:2.3.128.eng: an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
dn34:2.3.128.comm: The sutta, and hence the Dīgha Nikāya as a whole, ends with the qualities of the arahant, the one who completes the path and practice of the Buddha.

dn34:2.3.130.pli: Iti ime satadhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā”ti.
dn34:2.3.130.eng: So these hundred things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly understood by the Realized One.”

dn34:2.3.131.eng: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.

dn34:2.3.132.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
dn34:2.3.132.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
